definition: Fukuzawa Yukichi (1835-1901), prominent Japanese Westernizer, liberal educator and founder of Keio University
good fortune/happiness/luck
surname Fu/abbr. for Fujian province 福建省[Fu2 jian4 sheng3]
pool/pond/(of metals etc) luster/favor or beneficence/damp/moist
order (from above)
lucky/giga- (meaning billion or 10^9)
surname Ji/abbr. for Jilin Province 吉林省[Ji2 lin2 Sheng3]

sentences.english: Fukuzawayukichi holds that the final aim of the development of civilization is, the independence of Japanese nation.
sentences.chinese: 福泽谕吉认为文明发展的最终目的是日本的国家独立。

sentences.english: It will look at the East-West cultural ideologies from Youwei-kang and Yukichi-Fukuzawa's perspectives in the first section.
sentences.chinese: 第一部分主要探讨康有为与福泽谕吉的东西文化观。

definition: the Japanese Meiji Restoration of 1868
ITŌ Hirobumi (1841-1909), Japanese Meiji restoration politician, prime minister on four occasions, influential in Japanese expansionism in Korea, assassinated in Harbin
Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Oukubo Toshimichi (1830-1878), Japanese politician
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
to abandon the old (Asian) ways and learn from Europe/refers to the ideas that led to the Meiji Restoration and Japan's subsequent colonization projects in Asia
Ku Hung-ming or Gu Hongming (1857-1928), Malaysian man of letters, highly regarded for his literary works written mostly in English, and known for his monarchist views
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Huang Zunxian (1848-1905), Qing dynasty poet and diplomat, author of A Record of Japan 日本國誌|日本国志[Ri4 ben3 Guo2 zhi4], an extended analysis of Meiji Japan
First Sino-Japanese War (1894-95)
A Record of Japan, by Huang Zunxian 黃遵憲|黄遵宪[Huang2 Zun1 xian4], an extended analysis of Meiji Japan
the theory of evolution (early translation, since replaced by 進化論|进化论)
Tokyo Imperial University (renamed Tokyo University after 1945)
pinyin: Dong1 jing1 Di4 guo2 Da4 xue2
